title: Prefigurative Community Building (Part 33): Community Composting as Power With Nutrient Cycling
summary: A guide to creating community composting collectives that repair ecological relationships while building shared infrastructure through horizontal coordination.

Community.summary: Build shared composting infrastructure that strengthens neighborhood relationships and ecological awareness.

level0: Start neighborhood conversations about food waste and soil health
Begin small-scale composting in backyards or community spaces
Map local sources of organic waste and potential composting sites
level1: Form a composting collective with shared agreements and rotating roles
Set up collection routes using bikes, carts, or walking routes
Establish simple composting systems using accessible, low-tech methods
level2: Create community composting hubs that serve multiple neighborhoods
Host workshops and skill-shares on composting and soil building
Connect finished compost with local gardens and food growing projects
level3: Support formation of additional autonomous composting collectives
Build networks of community-controlled waste and nutrient cycling
Advocate for policy changes supporting community composting infrastructure

Knowledge.summary: Share practical composting knowledge while building understanding of ecological cycles and systems.

level0: Learn basic composting methods and soil science principles
Study successful community composting projects like LA Compost and BK ROT
level1: Practice different composting techniques and troubleshoot problems collectively
Document your composting process and share learning with others
Learn about waste streams and nutrient cycles in your bioregion
level2: Host workshops on composting, soil health, and waste reduction
Create accessible resources about community composting methods
Share knowledge with other composting collectives and gardening groups
level3: Develop comprehensive community composting toolkits and curricula
Research and document impacts of community-controlled vs municipal composting
Train facilitators and organizers in other communities

Narrative.summary: Challenge waste culture narratives while promoting stories of regeneration and ecological relationship.

level0: Share stories about the beauty and importance of soil and composting
Challenge narratives that treat organic matter as 'waste'
Practice seeing composting as relationship repair rather than chore
level1: Document the community benefits of shared composting infrastructure
Challenge extractive waste management systems in your area
Share stories of successful community composting and soil regeneration
level2: Lead community conversations about waste, consumption, and ecological cycles
Create media highlighting community composting as resistance to waste culture
Advocate for community-controlled rather than corporate waste management
level3: Contribute to cultural shift toward viewing waste as resource
Develop and share analysis of composting as ecological and social practice
Support broader movements for waste justice and ecological restoration
